title: Stile rappresentativo
text:
(Italian for "representative style") is an Italian <a href="opera">opera</a> term. It is a style of <a href="singing">singing</a> developed in the early <a href="Italian%20opera">Italian opera</a>s of the late 16th century that is more expressive than speech, but not as <a href="melody">melodious</a> as song. It is a dramatic <a href="recitative">recitative</a> style of the early <a href="Baroque">Baroque</a> era in which melodies move freely over a foundation of simple <a href="Chord%20%28music%29">chord</a>s.
In "The Concise Oxford Dictionary of Music", it is defined as follows:
stile rappresentativo (Italian, "In representational style"). Term used by early Italian <a href="composer">composer</a>s of opera and <a href="oratorio">oratorio</a> to describe their new device of <a href="recitative">recitative</a>, in which human speech was represented dramatically as in <a href="Jacopo%20Peri">Peri</a>'s "<a href="Euridice%20%28Peri%29">Euridice</a>" (1600) and <a href="Claudio%20Monteverdi">Monteverdi</a>'s "<a href="L%27Arianna">L'Arianna</a>" (1608).
